thread.title: Tom Brady goes all-in with defense of sketchy ‘body coach’
thread.title_full: Tom Brady goes all-in with defense of sketchy ‘body coach’ | New York Post

author: Howie Kussoy
title: Tom Brady goes all-in with defense of sketchy ‘body coach’
text:
Four games into the NFL season, Tom Brady’s decision-making looks better than ever, with the Patriots quarterback yet to throw an interception, but off the field, the 38-year-old’s judgment doesn’t appear to be as sharp.
After spending the entire offseason defending himself from Deflategate allegations, Brady is now facing criticism for his association with close friend, trainer and business partner Alex Guerrero, who was revealed to have been investigated by the Federal Trade Commission multiple times and punished for making inaccurate claims of being able to help cure cancer, AIDS and other diseases, according to Boston Magazine. 
When pressed about the issue on his regular radio spot on WEEI on Monday , Brady defended his friend, before quickly turning the conversation.
“We’ve talked about several things as it relates to that, and he dealt with that,” Brady said. “That’s part of his life and that’s something that happened 13 years ago. I know what I’ve spoke with Alex over the years, and I have tremendous belief in Alex and what he’s accomplished with me. In the 10 or 11 years we’ve been working together, he’s never been wrong.”
Brady jogs off the field after the Patriots beat the Cowboys on Sunday. Photo: Getty Images Before working on a daily basis as Brady’s “body coach,” Guerrero misidentified himself in an infomercial as a doctor while promoting a nutritional supplement called “Supreme Greens,” which supposedly could cure or prevent “cancer, heart disease, arthritis, and diabetes, as well as help lose 80 pounds in eight months,” according to a complaint filed by the FTC, using fake drug trials results to substantiate the “extraordinary claims” of a product referred to as “modern-day snake oil.”
Guerrero paid a $65,000 fine in 2005 as part of a settlement with the FTC, which prevented him from ever representing himself as a doctor or promoting Supreme Greens or a similar product. As part of a company called 6 Degree Nutrition, Guerrero was stopped again by the FTC a few years later after selling a drink — NeuroSafe — which supposedly helped improve recovery time from concussions.
“When you say, ‘Well, this sounds like quackery,’ there’s a lot of things I see on a daily basis in Western medicine that I think, ‘Wow, why would they ever do that? That is crazy.’ That’s just the way life works,” Brady said. “I don’t know the details of each of those incidences, but I think that it speaks to he as a person, as a friend. There’s nobody better person that I enjoy as much as Alex. He’s been an incredible influence in my life.”
Brady and Guerrero — who met in 2006 through former linebacker Willie McGinest — are business partners in a sports therapy center called TB12, located in Massachusetts. The future Hall of Famer said if it wasn’t for Guerrero, he “wouldn’t be playing today,” crediting him for changing his lifestyle, helping him recover from a devastating knee injury in 2008 and avoiding the type of injuries that usually prevent quarterbacks from winning Super Bowls and leading MVP races at age 38.
According to a New York Times profile , Guerrero is also the godfather of Brady’s son, Ben, and accompanies the quarterback to every game, standing on the sidelines. Guerrero plans Brady’s training schedule months in advance and coordinates his meals with New England’s staff.
“Everyone thinks I’m a kook and a charlatan,” Guerrero told the Times, when discussing traditional training methods.
Brady has even gotten several teammates to work with Guerrero, including receiver Julian Edelman and former All-Pro Wes Welker. At TB12, Guerrero sells his own line of nutritional supplements, which the trainer claims aren’t in violation of the NFL’s substance abuse policy. Brady said he was “absolutely” sure he has taken nothing that would result in more legal battles with the league.
“Willie used to be the big Alex evangelist, [but] now I’m the evangelist,” Brady said of Guerrero’s training and treatments. “It’s like giving a chef flour and eggs and saying, ‘OK, we’ll make biscuits.’ Well, sure, everyone is going to make them different. But Alex is perfect at it.”
